question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
Consider the matrix

\[A = \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
-6 & 8 \\
-4 & 6
\end{array} \right]\] Compute the eigenvalues of $A$Â~and a non-zero
eigenvector for each eigenvalue.
sols:
Eigenvalues are values of the variable λ such that the system

\[\displaystyle
A-\lambda I\] has a non-trivial nullspace or equivalently, when it has
determinant 0.

We compute this determinant:

\begin{align*}
\det(A-\lambda I) &= \left| \begin{array}{cc}
-6-\lambda & 8 \\
-4 & 6-\lambda
\end{array}\right| \\
&= (-6-\lambda)(6-\lambda) - 8(-4) \\
&= -36 + \lambda^2 + 32 \\
&= \lambda^2 - 4
\end{align*}

And so we conclude that this determinant is zero if and only if λ is 2
or -2. (Note: this equation is called the characteristic polynomial of
the linear system).

For each eigenvalue, an eigenvector is simply a non-trivial solution
(non-trivial means not zero since that's an obvious solution that is
always present).

For λ = 2 we obtain the system

\begin{align*}
A-2I &= \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
-8 & 8 \\
-4 & 4
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 & -1 \\
0 & 0
\end{array}\right] \\
\end{align*}

And so the general solution is a vector of the form {[}\emph{t},
\emph{t} {]}, which means that the eigenspace for the eigenvalue 2 is
spanned by the vector {[}1, 1{]}.

For λ = -2 we obtain the system

\begin{align*}
A+2I &= \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
-4 & 8 \\
-4 & 8
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 & -2 \\
0 & 0
\end{array}\right] \\
\end{align*}

And so the general solution is a vector of the form {[}2\emph{t},
\emph{t} {]}, which means that the eigenspace for the eigenvalue -2 is
spanned by the vector {[}2, 1{]}.
